statement:
If $(M,\omega)$ is a $2n$-dimensional symplectic manifold, and $m\in M$,
then there exists a neighborhood $U$ of $m$ with a coordinate chart
$$x=(x_1,\ldots,x_{2n}):U\to{\mathbb{R}}^{2n},$$ such that
$$\omega=\sum_{i=1}^ndx_{i}\wedge dx_{n+i}.$$ These are called canonical
or Darboux coordinates. On $U$, $\omega$ is the pullback by $X$ of the
standard symplectic form on ${\mathbb{R}}^{2n}$, so $x$ is a
symplectomorphism. Darboux’s theorem implies that there are no local
invariants in symplectic geometry, unlike in Riemannian geometry, where
there is curvature.
